captions.text:
The winter solstice,
the first day of winter

in the Northern Hemisphere, has
been celebrated all over the world

for thousands of years,
because for many cultures,
perhaps most famously the Maya,

it marks the end of one unit of
time and the beginning of another.

You know, the year.
I just like it because

it means that the days
are finally getting longer.
It gets dark at like 4:30

in the freakin' afternoon
in Montana right now!
[INTRO]

Now, I'm not going to insult
you by getting into what the

winter solstice does not mean,
vis a vis the end of the world.

But I can think of no
better time to open up

a big can o' anthropology
and dispel some of those

pernicious myths
about Maya civilization.

Number one:
This is not a Maya calendar.

People, please,
for the love of Pete,
if you get anything out of this,

just remember that this symbol
that you've been seeing everywhere

on cheap t-shirts and
even cheaper websites

has nothing to do with the
Maya or how they track time.

It's called the sun stone, and it
was actually carved by the Aztecs

a Mesoamerican culture
that followed the Maya

in the late 1400s,
about 500 years after

the Maya city-states
began to fall apart.

The face in the middle
is of the Aztec sun god,

and the ring around it features
the 20 days of the Aztec month.

But still, even this
is not a calendar.

It was carved to commemorate the
ascension of the ruler Itzcoatl

kind of like...it's like
a giant commemorative plate.

The Maya did use wonderfully
elaborate and accurate systems

for measuring time that you
can learn more about here.

But there's no rock carving or
anything else that could be described

as a Maya calendar that's
like, analagous to the thing

that's hanging in your kitchen
and tells you what day it is
and has kittens or firemen on it.

Myth Number Two:
The Maya language is indecipherable.

For a long time it was,
actually until pretty recently.

For centuries anthropologists
tried and failed to translate

ancient Maya writing, which led
to the meme of "The Maya Code."

But it's not a secret code,
it's a language just like any other.

It consists of about 700 glyphs,
written from left to right

and top to bottom,
in lines two glyphs long.
Bit by bit, one clue at a time,

scientists figured out
how the system worked.

One of the biggest breakthroughs
came in the late 20th century,

when anthropologists realized
that the glyphs represented

both sounds or syllables,
and individual ideas,

and that each ancient
city-state had its own dialect,

just to get a little
bit more confusing for you.

So, to write the word for jaguar,
b'alam, one group might use

a glyph that literally
represents a jaguar,

while another might write it
out phonetically: ba - la - ma.

Today, we can read about
90% of all of the carvings

and handwritten books produced
in the original Maya language,

and modern Maya
throughout Central America

are writing in it again for
the first time in centuries.

Myth Number Three: The Ancient
Maya Were Peaceful Geniuses

A hundred years ago,
all we knew about the Maya was
how smart they were.

How they could predict the
movement of the Sun and the moon
and the planets down to the minute,

and how they built huge stone
temples without metal tools,

and farmed in the
mountains by terracing land.

So for a long time most scientists
thought that the Maya were a

peaceful people whose main interest
was looking up at the sky.

But, once we became able to read
what their monuments and books

had to say, we realized
that, much like us,

they were smart about
science and dumb about people.

They actually spent a lot of
time warring with each other,

and on rare occasions they even
sacrificed people for ritual purposes.

Not virgins though.
Usually people captured in battle.

But the Maya didn't do anything near
the scale that the Aztecs did.

Trust me, you do not want to be
caught downtown in Tenochtitlan
after a bad corn harvest,

or when the king was cutting the
ribbon on a new temple or something.

Basically, the Maya
were like everyone else:
smart, flawed and awesome.

Thank you for watching
this SciShow Dose.

If you have any questions or
comments or suggestions for us,

we're on Facebook and Twitter and
of course, down in the comments below.

And if you want to keep getting
smarter with us here at SciShow

you can go to
youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

title: Calendars, Codes & Virgins: 3 Myths About the Maya

comments.text:
I wonder where the stories about 'sacrificing virgins' came from in the 
first place?  In cultures before the Industrial Revolution, the concept of 
virgin the way we understand it didn't really exist.  'Virgin' was used to 
either refer to any young woman - saying nothing about their sexual 
experience - or referred to a woman who had not yet given birth.  The idea 
that there would be someone who has never had sex would have been very 
bizarre to pre-Industrial people.  Sex was pretty much ever-present in 
pre-Industrial cultures.  Families didn't even have separate bedrooms, they 
all slept - and screwed - in common rooms.  People grew up witnessing sex 
from before they could remember.  They simply didn't know a world in which 
people didn't have sex on a regular basis.  And since they couldn't get 
pregnant or get someone else pregnant, their sex play was seen as 
harmless.  Sex was as normal as eating or sleeping.  It was just something 
fun to do that felt good.  The idea that someone would grow up and never 
experience it was such a bizarre idea that the only time it was even 
suggested was in stories about their version of superheroes - saints.﻿
comments.author: Dustin Rodriguez

comments.text:
So basically what he's saying is that what we would of the Maya is actually 
more representative of the Aztec. And that famous "Calendar" thing people 
see on these cheap websites has actually nothing to do with calendars or 
the Maya, is Aztec in origin, and originally served as some sort of 
"monumental plate". 

Ancient Aliens I'm lookin' at you. 

Does anybody know that journalist on that show again? The guy with a goofy 
haircut, what's his face? Oh, and his name's not "Ancient Alien Guy", 
because I know that for sure. ﻿

comments.text:
Thank you for clearing this out, im from Mexico and currently working on 
some motion graphics on the proper reading of the Aztec calendar also 
called "Tonalpohualli" I wasn't really aware of this but most of the 
foreign people at some point for some reason took this calendar as the main 
symbol for the Mayan culture and wrap it around all this controversial 
prophecies bout the end of the world, and it has being really annoying 
reading all this papers about people misunderstanding the whole function or 
us being stupid for believing such prophecies, so here are some interesting 
and actual facts about the Aztec calendar that I've recently learned in a 
surprising unexpected investigation : the calendar was actually trying to 
compute 2 different cycles within its structure, the humans cycle or 
"destiny" which was represented by (260 days*divided in 20 blocks of 13 
days) and the earths cycle (365 days*divided in 18 blocks of of 20 days)+5 
days in order to keep the calendar year synchronized with the astronomical 
or seasonal year. because seasons and astronomical events do not repeat in 
a whole number of days and by inserting an additional day or month into the 
year, the drift can be corrected. this deficit has being solved in 
calendars by others civilizations in different ways for example in the 
Gregorian calendar, the current standard calendar in most of the world, in 
each leap year, February has 29 days instead of 28, Adding an extra day to 
the calendar every four years compensates for the fact that a period of 365 
days is shorter than a solar year by almost 6 hours ( this calendar was 
first used in 1582 ) this means it phases out 1 day every 3,200 years, the 
Muslim calendar phases out 1 day every 2,500 years, while the Jew and Egypt 
calendar only had exactitude of 1 day every 300 hundred years. because of 
the Aztec calendar added 5 extra days and started the year 4 days earlier 
every 520 years plus dividing the whole astronomical spectrum in fractions, 
it takes 9,000 years for this calendar to phase out 1 day, with an annual 
deficit of 11 min, which makes it the most precise and accurate calendar 
nowadays along with the Mayan ( which is a different calendar ) based on 
the same principles that were established by the ancient Toltecas, Mexicas, 
Nahuas or Aztecas. whats remarkable its that according to records this two 
civilizations never met in its contemporary splendor, they also divided 
their calendar in 4 orientations and 5 "Suns" which are attached to the 
exact cycle of equinoxes and this is why there is no place for a sixth 
"Sun" in the calendar, it also takes the Sun, Earth and Venus  8 years to 
align 5 times in the celestial sky (13 Venus orbits/ 8 Earth's orbits) the 
Aztecs and Mayas had the "Tzoltzin" to compute 260 days/7200 times to 
contain 360 days/5200 times to get the equivalent of 5 cycles (early/late 
morning,evening, early/late night) of 5,125 tropic years each =25,625 years 
( the amount of time it takes the galaxy to complete a spin or cycle around 
the sun called "Galactic day") The age of our solar system is about 20 of 
these revolutions. the mathematically result geometry of all this 
representations is the golden spiral and pentagram which is also formed by 
the beginning points at the 20 blocks of  the 13 days countdown, this is 
explained repeatedly within the calendar in 4 absolute languages: symbolic, 
numeric, chromatic and geometric, each day contains the influence of the 
corresponding past cycles and also points the variables on the equation 
which is called Trenza del tiempo or "Time braid '', so in my opinion maybe 
this calendars were only trying to quantify the beginning and end of 
galactic days or cycles in relation with earth's orientation and 
astronomical proximity to the sun.﻿

comments.text:
The Mayan calender (that I visited, at least) was this amazing building in 
Mexico. It was this massive pyramid that used the position of the sun to 
measure time to an insanely specific degree. It also had these weird 
acoustic functions, like if you clapped directly infront of the calendar on 
it's north(?) face, you would hear a quite defined snake's hiss to your 
left (snakes are holy in Mayan culture). They also had this big stone that 
thousands of executions were preformed upon. Fascinating.

comments.text:
Another interesting myth regarding sacrifice involves that famous Mayan 
ball game (I forget its technical name), in which everyone says the loser 
would be sacrificed. However, based on textual evidence, it was actually 
the winner who would be sacrificed, cause the gods don't want some second 
banana! Interesting stuff
